INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring notification to community boards and council members of applications for issuance of alteration permits for cellular telephone antennas and equipment.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Notification to community boards and council members of applications for issuance of alteration permits for cellular telephone antennas and equipment.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to noise levels during protests and demonstrations.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Noise levels during protests and demonstrations.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the federal government to only purchase military uniforms made wholly in the United States, and to give New York City its fair share of military uniform purchasing contracts.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Federal government to only purchase military uniforms made wholly in the US.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the appropriate committee of the Council of the City of New York to hold a hearing to review federal standards and guidelines for determining where to locate traffic control devices and whether they are appropriate for New York City.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Review federal standards and guidelines for determining where  to locate traffic control devices and whether they are appropriate for NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the prohibition of inhumane activities and practices used in rodeos.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Prohibition of inhumane activities and practices used in rodeos.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring that commercial shopping establishments that maintain a parking area of at least 200 spaces install, maintain and operate surveillance cameras in order to deter crime.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Require commercial shopping establishments that maintain a parking area of at least 200 spaces install, maintain and operate surveillance cameras in order to deter crime.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting locksmiths and car dealers from reproducing ignition keys in specific circumstances.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting locksmiths and car dealers from reproducing ignition keys in specific circumstances.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the resale of undergarments.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting the resale of undergarments.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the collection of claims on behalf of the city of New York.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Collection of claims on behalf of the city of New York.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to horse drawn cabs.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Horse drawn cabs

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the enforcement of stop-work orders issued by the department of buildings.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Enforcement of stop-work orders issued by the department of buildings.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to dividing the 109th precinct into two distinct subdivisions.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Dividing the 109th precinct into two distinct subdivisions.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon Governor Pataki and the New York State Legislature to request that the United States Congress amend or repeal the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act to allow states to legalize betting on sporting events, and further calling upon the United States Congress to change this law so that New York State can legalize betting on sporting events and use all revenue generated from this activity for education funding.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Amend or repeal the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to remove New York City Transit and MTA Bus Company from the control of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) and transfer control to the city of New York or in the alternative to cede greater decision making authority in the planning and operations of NYCT and MTA Bus Company to the City of New York.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Remove NYC Transit and MTA Bus Company from the control of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA).

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor and the Fire Department of the City of New York to abide by the laws as set forth in the Laws of New York, 2002, Chapter 468, Part A, §3, concerning the full active employment status of James J. Corrigan, William Wren, and Phillip T. Hayes by the Fire Department of the City of New York on September 11, 2001, including their eligibility for all rights and privileges as active duty firefighters.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Criminal Justice Services
Items.MatterName: Mayor and the FDNY to abide by the laws as set forth in the Laws of New York, 2002.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend Sections 458 and 458-a of the New York Real Property Tax Law, in relation to extending partial property tax exemption provisions of such sections to the school tax portion of New York State property taxes for qualified veterans.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Extending partial property tax exemption provisions of such sections to the school tax portion of NYS property taxes for qualified veterans.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Dilan, S.1282, and Assembly Member Robinson, A.2455, “AN ACT to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the registration of property and designation of mailing address”.

Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.

Items.MatterName: NYS to end the real property tax exemption granted to Madison Square Garden ("MSG" or the "Garden").

Items.MinutesNote: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

At this point, there was a Moment of Silence in Memory of:

Army Spc. Marlon A. Bustamonte, 25, of Corona, N.Y., killed by improvised explosive device in Baghdad, Iraq on February 1, 2006 (1st Battalion, 502nd Infrantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division); leaves behind his wife , his twin 2 year old sons anda month old daughter.

Army Spc. Sergio Mercedes Saez, 23, of Manhattan, N.Y., killed when his Humve veered off road into a canal in  in Baghdad, Iraq on February 5, 2006 (2nd Battalion, 502nd Infrantry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division) ; leaves behind his wife who is expecting their first child in March.

Police Officer Eric Hernandez (52nd Precinct, the Bronx), died on February 8, 2006 from gunshot wounds from friendly-fire incident.

Betty Friedan, died on her 85th birthday on Februrya 4, 2006, feminist women's advocate.

Jill Chaifetz, died on February 2, 2006 of ovarian cancer, Executive Director of Advocates for Children in New York.
